speechtext: I may say this is dated at Canarvon, 22nd March, 1900, and is addressed to the C. S. O., Ottawa, that is the chief staff officer, Ottawa. It goes on from day to day, giving reports to the department here, as I take it, and is signed T. D. B. Evans, Lt.-Col. Comndg. 2nd Bn., C.M.R.
Then, I think it would be in order to ask my hon. friend how he came into possession of it. If it is, an official document, I think we have a right to know.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I can say I found it in a drawer. I do not know who put it there, I will admit that much, and that is all I can admit. That drawer I am in the habit of using myself.

There is no doubt about its being an official document.
Mr. SPROTjLE. Would the minister tell us about the number of rifles we have, and also give us some information regarding the quality of the ammunition ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: The only ammunition which we have had here which was not up to the proper standard, was ammunition which we purchased from the War Office. That was admitted to be bad. or not quite what it ought to be; and after having a report by the superintendent of the cartridge factory we asked parliament to vote, I think, a sum of $15,000 to make these cartridges all right. That money was voted, and the cartridges have been made good. The Imperial government, recognizing that we were not to blame in the matter, that they were responsible, have repaid the amount. As to the quantity of arms, we have 40,000 stand of Lee-Enfield and Lee-Metford rifles. As to the quantity of ammunition, I am not able to state the exact amount. Perhaps it is not desirable that I should. But I may say that it is not up to the reserve quantity that we ought to have, that we are increasing the capacity of the cartridge factory now to about four times what it was, in the hope that in a very few years we shall have a very large reserve indeed, a satisfactory reserve of ammunition, in fact the reserve which the intelligence branch of the .War Office required or advised.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: There is another matter I desire to mention, and one to which I drew the attention of the hon. gentleman last year, and that is the cadet corps. Would the hon. gentleman explain what he has done to supply the cadet corps with ammunition, & c.?
I may tell my hon. friend we have not supplied any ammunition to the cadet corps.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: The hon. gentleman, I think, suggested this afternoon that he proposed to bring down a Bill at the next session to provide that before any soldier is allowed to join the active service he has to he thoroughly tested in the matter of shooting.
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
And I notice, according to the report, he is supplying associations or clubs with free ammunition and rifles, I presume, they have got to give a bond for a proper care of the, rifle ?
THE MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE. Yes.

Now we have, speaking of my own city alone, a cadet corps, I think about 60 strong. They have taken a great interest in drill, and I think the department has supplied them with ammunition to some extent, and some tubes, I believe.
Yes, the Morris tube.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I think great encouragement ought to be given to the cadet corps, the citizens take a great deal of interest In them, and have subscribed for uniforms for these boys in order to encourage them. So far as our own cadet corps is concerned, Col. Peters inspected them, and no officer could make a better report than he has made of the cadet corps in St. Thomas. They have competed with the cadet corps of London and of Chatham, and with others. It strikes me as a singular thing that clubs or associations throughout the country can be supplied with free ammunition and free rifles, subject of course to a bond for proper care when so little attention is paid to the cadet corps of our country. I think cadet corps ought to be encouraged in every possible way, and if there is any free ammunition to be given, and plenty of it, they should be supplied. They are generally young men leaving collegiate institutes, 18 or 19 or 20 years of age, and very often they join the different battalions wherever they are located. These young boys will be eventually the defenders of our country, and the drilling and training they are receiving as cadets is of very great importance to them and to the country as well. So I say again, on behalf of the cadet corps, that more attention ought to given to them, and that the department ought not to be too particular in regard to supplying them, but that it should supply them as liberally as can be done.

I think there is a great deal of force in what the hon. member for East Mr. INGRAM.
Elgin (Mr. Ingram) said, but we cannot do everything at once. I have my doubts as to whether, under the present law, we have the power without asking a special vote of parliament to do what he requests. If the law is revised, or if a new law is passed, there will be a-n opportunity then to make some provision for this. The age of the militiaman is now from eighteen years up,-whereas, many of the cadets are under that age, and they are not, strictly speaking, members of the militia. They are, however, most important features of the militia, and I quite agree that to the utmost of our ability we should encourage them and give them the means of learning how to shoot. That can be done at a much younger age than eighteen, the lowest age for joining the militia. I have not forgotten the matter and the hon. gentleman can rest assured that I will do whatever I can to encourage these cadet corps.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
Not being a military man I cannot discuss the question in military terms, because I have not been taught them. There is another thing that I omitted to mention and that was the question of tents.
I notice in the report that there is somethinglike 500 damaged tents at the departmental stores. I know that the cadet corps have applied frequently to the department for the use of these tents in order that they might camp out for a certain time in the summer. They have been refused on the ground that if the department were to give them to one cadet corps they would be obliged to give a great many of them to the different cadet corps throughout the Dominion. If there are 500 of these tents that are of no use for the regular militia, surely it would not be out of place to supply the cadet corps with these, because I understand they have a thorough system upon going into camp. They try as far as possible to conduct themselves on the same lines as those laid down for militiamen when they go into regular camp. This is a movement that should be encouraged and instead of obliging them to buy tents for themselves, or to borrow them, I think the department should supply them. So far as the vote of this House is concerned,' 1 have been here long enough to know that when a number of years ago the militia estimates were before this House, the members of the House certainly did not act in a very friendly manner towards the Department of Militia. They were, if I may use the word, too stingy with the public moneys in their grants to the Militia Department, but I think, perhaps, since the difficulty in South Africa has occurred, a more generous spirit has prevailed amongst the members of the House in regard to granting more money to the Militia Department. So far as I am personally concerned, while the Militia Department to-day is asking for a considerable sum of money, I am willing to vote a greater sum than we are

providing the department with now. 1 have always believed, and I believe now, as a civilian having no military knowledge, that when we have good men in this conn-try, men of ability willing to devote a large part of their time and to incur personal expense to assist in drilling our young men in order to make them soldiers, available in time of need for the defence of this country, the country has received too much at the hands of these men and that the members of this House have not come to this House with a view of assisting them as much as they should have done. I think the officers in our militia should receive greater encouragement and that they should not be called upon to pay out large sums of money for the purpose of helping their particular corps. I know men in the province of Ontario who, being too proud to allow their battalions to go down, have put their hands into their own pockets for the purpose of making their battalions a success, and I have known these very same men to leave their battalions a great deal poorer than when they joined them. Why this should be is beyond all comprehension.
I think we should give them all the encouragement we can reasonably, consistent with the other expenditures which we make throughout the country.

I would like to say one word in respect to the question of tents for the cadets. It is quite true that the Militia Department was in the habit of loaning a certain number of tents to the cadets, and as far as I know, they were well taken care of. But since we have taken to drilling the whole militia every year in camp, we have had to use all available tents and at the same time we found the demands \>n the part of the cadets increasing so that there was no alternative for us but to stop issuing them. We also had to consider, when the question became a large one, as to whether we had the right or not to issue these tents. The very same point that I suggested a moment ago in regard to rifles and ammunition, arises in reference to the supply of tents. I do not know that parliament authorizes us to supply tents. As to the damaged tents, I did hope that we might perhaps give these to the cadets, but my officers advised me that there was only one way in which that could be done, and that was by offering them at auction and have some one bid them in. I suggested that, but I do not think that suggestion was accepted. We must offer everything at public auction. There is no alternative, but I should be very glad indeed to facilitate in every way in my power the securing of these tents by the cadets or by some one in their behalf.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
Am I correct in understanding that all of these cadet corps will be supplied with rifles ? Is it only cadet
corps in connection with collegiate institutes and high schools that will receive them, or cadet corps raised in any portion of the country ?
The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND
DEFENCE. Cadet corps in any portion of the country.

Is there any limit as to age in	the cadet corps ?
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. Yes, there is an age limit of fourteen.

The cadets must be between fourteen and eighteen years of age V
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. Yes.

Then the issue of rifles will apply to any cadet corps in any portion of the country ?
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. Yes.
I see that a large share of this vote is for clothing and stores, How do you buy clothing and stores ? Is it. by tender or do you just give an order to a large house ?

The clothing during the last two or three years has been purchased from the same contractors with whom we made a contract three years ago. The Sanford Co., who were the contractors when I came in and who have been most satisfactory, and a firm in Montreal by the name of Workman, which has done a great deal for us and which has also been very satisfactory, are the contractors. The contract was made for three years under the late government, and although when I came into office I did not think it was a good arrangement I was glad to be able to state In the House last year that the system was a wise one. As a matter of fact we terminated several three years contracts, because the then Minister of Justice reported that they were illegal. We advertized for tenders in all the papers In all the cities of the Dominion, and I am bound to say that I never had so much trouble about anything in my life. A firm took a contract for about $70,000 which knew nothing about the work and absolutely failed to deliver any goods whatever. We had to go back to the Sanfords and ask them to do the work for us. After that experience, and on the advice of my officers I have felt that it was wiser for us and better in the public interest to stick to the bridge that has carried us safely over. I am satisfied that the prices we are paying are not extravagant That matter is carefully looked into and a report made on it. Although the price of cloth increased last year we were able to get our clothing made at practically the same rates as before and very satisfact-I orily.	.	.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
Will tlie minister say if it is proposed to make any change in the kind of clothing ?
The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND; DEFENCE. Well I think it is, although the matter is under consideration. I think myself that we might have more comfortable clothing at less expenditure than at present, and I asked the General to look into that matter. I hope that some result will come of the inquiries which he is making.
Do you keep any quantity of clothing in stock ? How will you equip the new contingent for instance ?

We will have to give an order for the clothing. Unfortunately we have no reserve of clothing. I found very little when I came in and we have been using a great deal in the camps and in the reviews during the visit of Their Royal Highnesses when we had 20,000 men out. We have not been able to accumulate a reserve. I hope under the terms of this vote that possibly we may be able this year to do with less in camp, and add something to our reserve. It is very important we should do so, but I did not feel at liberty to ask a special vote for it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I was very much surprised to hear from the member for East , Elgin that the cadet company in St. Thomas had been supplied with Morris tubes for rifle practice. I know that a great many cadet companies from the different high schools have petitioned the Minister of Militia for Morris tubes but without success. The Minister of Education was presented with a petition from all the high schools in the province of Ontario, and was asked to make representations to the Minister of Militia about it. I cannot understand why one school should get this tube and all the others not. I think they should all be treated on the same principle. It is very important that these young men should have a chance of getting rifle practice which is perhaps the most important of the manoeuvres of war. I hope the minister will see that all schools are treated alike, and that all the cadet companies shall be supplied with these Morris tubes. I understand that there is a grant made to those companies of $50 each or altogether about $1,750 for drilling. It will cost very little more to provide these tubes so as to enable the cadets to study this important part of military service.
The MINISTER OF MILITIA Ai\D DEFENCE. I can assure my hon. friend (Mr. Clare) that there is no intention on my part to discriminate. I was not aware that any Morris tubes had been supplied to cadets. I know that an application has been made, but the fact is that we had not a sufficient number to comply with that application. I will inquire and we shall certainly treat all glike.
Then, is it the intention of the minister to supply the different cadet companies with Morris tubes ?

I am informed by the Deputy Minister that we have not supplied any. It is quite possible that in the case referred to the tubes may have been secured from the local militia, and possibly that arrangement might be made in other instances.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: It would appear then that the department has done nothing to encourage the cadet corps. They have not allowed them to have tents.
We have supplied rifles.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: You gave them no ammunition.
No.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: They would be like wooden guns then.
There is plenty of ammunition to be purchased.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: No better use could be made of the money that is devoted to militia purposes, then in supplying these cadet corps with tents so that they may camp out. They go into the business not for the 75 cents a day but for mere love and enthusiasm, and when they are young and enthusiastic is the time to make soldiers of them. Tlie militia department should supply the cadets with tents and Morris tubes. I think the minister should take that suggestion into his serious consideration and try to do something during the coming summer.
The militia department has sent officers to inspect these different cadet corps.
And we have supplied drill instructors from the permanent force.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I see that there is but one slight reference to the cadets in the whole of the militia report. Would it not be well to publish the report of these inspecting officers so that we may know what progress they are making.
That suggestion is a very good one. The cadets of course are not part of the militia, and there is no vote taken for them.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Do I understand that no Morris tubes were issued to the cadet corps.
The Deputy Minister informs me that there were not any issued.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: What did the minister say as to supplying tents for the cadets '!

We really have not the tents available. If I could I would gladly facilitate the cadets in securing tents that are reported as unlit for military use, but we must go through the form of selling them by public auction.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I desire to take the opportunity of saying that on two or three occasions when I asked the minister to facilitate the camping out of the companies of the boys brigade, he very kindly placed at their disposal tents that were not quite up to the mark for military purposes. Possibly he might be able to do something of that kind for the cadets.
I will look into that suggestion.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE..

speechtext: I should think too, that the senior members of the cadet corps might possibly be supplied with a certain quantity of ammunition.
I understand that the supplies, after they become used up, chn only be sold legally by public auction.
Yes, or by public tender.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: That was not done with rifles that were sold at twenty-five cents each.
Yes, by public tender advertised in every paper in all the large cities in Canada. That matter was threshed out here. I laid the papers on the Table. The hon. gentleman has forgotten it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: When you submit the Bill next session you might provide that the damaged tents should be given to the cadet corps.
I think provision might be made to include the cadets in the militia of the country, and I may say that is under consideration. Then there would be no difficulty.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I notice also that the report calls attention to the fact that many of the aiming tubes were out of order. It says
In one instance 33 out of a total of 48 were returned serviceable, as many as seven bullets having to be removed from one tube.
Is that owing to the carelessness of the men using them or to the tubes not being perfect ?
I cannot tell my hon. friend. I think that it must be due to carelessness.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: In the petition to the minister to which I have referred they asked that some of the discarded staff sergeants' swords should be given to the officers of the cadet corps. I understand that each company would like to have three swords, and if they are discarded and of no use to the department, I do not see why they should not be given to the cadet corps.
No reason at all. I think that ought to be done. I will look into it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I think some of these young cadets could hardly lift a cavalry sword. It would be rather heavy for them.

I observe that the Major General in his report expresses disapproval of the abolition of canteens on the ground that soldiers are liable to go to hotels and indulge in spirits whereas they would be content with a glass of beer if they could get it in the canteen in camp. Has the hon. minister any particular view himself on this question ? I know he was attacked very severely a few years ago for allowing the canteens to exist, and he assured those who were attacking him that it was his intention to abolish them. If the commanding-officer in his report recommends them, and if only ales are allowed to be sold in them, on the ground that they would prevent the soldiers going outside and indulging too freely, I think it would be a step in the right direction to re-establish them, notwithstanding all that has been said against them. There is no doubt that while there may be a good many temperance men in camp, there are others who believe in taking a glass of ale-perhaps more than that.
Two of them.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Yes, two of them. I think we ought not to be guided too much by sentiment in this matter. I think common sense ought to prevail, and that the Major General's recommendation should be carried out. I am not advocating the drinking of liquor by soldiers, but they may think at times that they should have a glass of ale, and I see no good reason why they should be deprived of it.

If my hon. friend were clothed with responsibility of office possibly he would not be quite so free to express his opinion. The fact is that when I came into office I found the regulation to which the Major General takes exception in existence, although some people have supposed that it was adopted quite recently. That regulation has been in existence for ten years or more. While the Major General is quite within his right in expressing his own opinion, I am not myself inclined to recommend the wiping out of that regulation. If a man requires a glass of beer, if it is essential

to liis health, there is a way of getting it, the surgeon can prescribe it. If he really needs anything of that kind it can be got in that way. * If he is perfectly well he can get along very well with tea or coffee or ginger ale. I am inclined to think that our lady friends, who take a great interest in the militia, would view the abolition of this regulation as a retrograde step, and I do not propose at this moment to take the risk of making them the enemies of the militia organization. I think, therefore, the regulation will have to continue.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
Lest I should be thought to have misrepresented the position of the Major General, I think it would be well to place on ' Hansard ' his recommendation on this subject, and if hon. gentlemen have no objection, I will read it for that purpose. He says this :
I would n*ot on any account permit the sale of spirits in the canteens during annual drill, but I must here most strongly protest against a system that forces a soldier, if he needs a glass of beer, to resort to the saloons and drinking shops of the nearest town where there is no control over either the quality, nature, or quantity of the liquor supplied to him. The effect of this regulation is to largely increase the amount of drunkenness in camp, and it is easy to show why this is so. In a military canteen all liquor has to be consumed on the premises and, if proper supervision is exercised, no man shall be served with more than is good Mr him. But what, happens under the. existing system of prohibition ? The man who would have been contented with his glass of ale or lager beer had he been able to procure it in camp, has to walk some distance to get his drink, probably takes whiskey instead of malt liquor, and very often returns to camp with a bottle of bad whiskey under his coat which he takes to his tent and proceeds to make his comrades intoxicated.
I contend that it is a serious evil to drive our men into the temptation of the city liquor bars, rather than let them buy a glass of wholesome beer in their own camp, and I trust that this incentive to intemperance may be removed from the militia regulations.
There is no doubt that the Major General has had a great deal of experience of soldiers, both in the old country and in Canada, and if his observation of their habits and customs has led him to make this recommendation, and it will be the means of preventing the too free use of spirits, and is really a step in the direction of temperance, I think his recommendation should be carried out. If it be in the interest of temperance, as he says it is-and I am sure he ought to be the better judge than some of those who object-in my judgment we should adopt the recommendation of the Major General.
Have the various corps the right to store their arms at their own headquarters ?

The General commanding recommends that we should go back to the - Hon. Mr. BORDEN (King's).
old system of issuing the rifles to the captains- of companies at company headquarters, and that is being done now.
Mr. CLARKE, Have we disposed of canteen business ?
speakername: The MINISTER OP MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I intend to leave tbe regulation as it is.
speakername: The MINISTER OP MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I do not quite understand the explanation of the minister with regard to the increase of $440,000 to $520,000. Are $150,000 more to be voted in the supplementaries ?

The fact is that the annual drill of the whole militia costs $425,000, and the custom has been to vote $275,000 for the first part of the year and $150,000 for the balance. But there is not much to be said in defence of that system. I ask the one sum, and it is not my intention to ask any supplementary estimates for the years 1902-3. But there will be a supplementary asked for this year 1901-2, as a portion of the militia go into camp in June, and it will require $135,000 to $150,000 to drill them. This vote will be sufficient for the year from 1st July, 1902 to the 30th June, 1903.
speakername: The MINISTER OP MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
There is really no increase ?
The	MINISTER	OP	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. No, it is a reduction.

Comparing it with the estimate of 1900, which was $275,000, and adding the $150,000, would make $425,000.
The	MINISTER	OP	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. Yes.

And this includes something further ?
The	MINISTER	OP	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. Clothing and stores.

I think this is a very much better way than to have two votes. I objected to that system of supplementary votes last year. I could see no reason why all the departments should not do as the hon. gentleman has done in this case, namely, bring down the whole estimate in the first place, so that the House may judge what amount the minister thinks will be requisite for the expenditure of the year. I made a formal protest against the other system last year, and suggested to the Minister of Finance that this change should be adopted and I am glad it has been in this case. It is a more business like way of dealing with the matter.
Salaries and wages, $90,000.

The increase here of $10,000 is due to the fact that we have had to employ more men and give them higher wages.

Higher wages^are being paid in every other department of the government, and we found it absolutely necessary to increase them here. We increased last year the pay something like 25 cents per day for each man, and I hope we will be able to get along this year without further increase.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE..

speechtext: Has the hon. minister considered the propriety of giving the first contingent the same pay as was received by the second ? That was brought to the attention of parliament last session, and he said he would consider the matter.

Before the supplementaries come down I may be able to give an answer. The matter was discussed last session and I thought it seemed to be the sense of the House that the law, as it stood, should not be disturbed. However, I will bring the matter up again in council, and have it discussed and give an answer later.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I think the feeling is very general, in view of the splendid services rendered by the men of the first contingent, that it was an invidious distinction to pay them a much smaller per diem allowance than the men who succeeded them.
I am satisfied that if the minister should ask parliament to vote the amount necessary to increase the pay of the men, it would be cheerfully done. The pay did not influence the men of the first contingent, or those of the second contingent either, and I think that the men of the first contingent are entitled to as much per diem as the men who followed them.
' Militia-chargeable to income-military properties, $190,000.

Some time ago, discussing the Sussex armoury, I made a statement which I wish to correct. I found some fault with the architect who designed the armoury and who had apportioned the different parts of it to the several corps. I think that I stated at that time that the compartments that were to be given to each company of the infantry were made the same size as those set apart for each squadron of cavalry. I was speaking from recollection of what had been said to me. I find that, technically, I was wrong. But, practically I was right. The armoury is divided into two equal portions, one half being devoted to the 8th regiment of cavalry, and the other to the 74th battalion. Now, the 74th battalion consists of six companies, with the total strength of 278. The cavalry has a total strength of 359, or nearly a hundred more than the infantry. In the case of the cavalry, there is the horse equipment, and the equipment of a horse will occupy fully as much space as the equipment of a man. The compartments were not as I stated they were, of equal size, for there are six compartments in one half, one for the use of the quartermaster
and the others for the use of the companies; in the other case there are five compartments, one for the use of the quartermaster, and four for the accoutrements of men and horses. Generally speaking, the point I made was that the same amount of room was devoted to the 74th battalion as was devoted to the 8th cavalry, though the cavalry consisted of something like eighty more men than the infantry and also had	the	equipment	of	the horses toconsider.	Therefore,	my	contention wasa proper one, and there is actually not	room enough	for	this regimentof cavalry and its equipment. I think that	at	that time	the	minister said
that the Oliver equipment when issued to the men, would take up a good deal more room. But, even so, I must persist in my claim that the division is not properly made, if it is made along the lines suggested.

When my hon. friend (Mr. Fowler) made the statement, I felt that it was an important one, because it seemed to reflect upon the work of the architect. The question is not so much as to how the space is divided, for it is possible the 74th regiment might be increased in strength, or, if there was extra room another infantry corps might be accommodated, for this room is not necessarily limited to the 74tli. But the real question is the one to which the hon. gentleman referred at the end of his remarks-is there sufficient accommodation for the cavalry ? The hon gentleman says there is not. But my officers say that there is.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I may say that my authority is the quartermaster of the 8th Hussars, who ought to know.
Did the hon. gentleman (Mr. Fowler) speak to the colonel about it ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I did not happen to see the colonel, but the quartermaster would know more about it than the colonel.

I understand that the' plan was submitted to the colonel before the work was gone on with, and he approved of it. The chief engineer of the department says that the plan was prepared by him, giving the accommodation asked for by the General Officer commanding.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I notice that the chief engineer of the Militia Department has made a recommendation, as follows :
The present system by which the Public Works Department construct all military buildings1 fs very unsatisfactory, and considerable trouble and delay is occasioned thereby. I would strongly urge the necessity of having the construction, as well as the maintenance and repairs of these buildings under the charge of the engineer branch of the Department of Militia and Defence.

Has any step been taken on that direction, or is that recommendation to be acted upon ?

No steps have been taken in that direction, and I do not feel at liberty to discuss the matter until the policy of the government with reference to it has been settled. It is no harm, however, for me to say that there is a good deal of inconvenience resulting from the fact that the work for the Militia Department is being done by the Department of Public Works. The same condition of tilings existed for many years in the Department of Marine and Fisheries, and, I think while Sir Charles Hibbert Tupper was minister, or perhaps earlier, a change was made by which the Department of Marine and Fisheries did their own work of constructing lighthouses and so on. There would certainly be many advantages in having the work done by the Militia Department itself.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
As I understand, these armouries are for the purpose of keeping the arms and accoutrements in a proper state. I notice that at page 41, the Major General commanding reports :
So soon as district staff adjutants are appointed to all the military districts, more frequent inspections of the arms and equipment of rural companies should be made, and this would minimize the risk of deterioration ; but I strongly recommend that, to make inspections more effective, a thoroughly qualified armourer should form part of the staff of each military district, who should accompany the stall officer at all inspections.
Have these district staff adjutants been appointed ?
No.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Have the armourers been appointed ?
I believe there are qualified armourers in nearly all, if not all, the military districts.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: May I ask if the district staff adjutant for military district No. 1 has been appointed ?
That is the London district ? No.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: What arrangement has been made for the taking care of the arms and accoutrements of the mounted rifles in the west ?
So far as I know, they are under the control of the commanding officer.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Have any arrangements been made for the renting of a building to keep them in ?

No, there is a money allowance that is supposed to be sufficient to cover everything. As a matter of fact the captains have usually buildings of their own, and they are given lump sums of money for taking care of the buildings.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MJLITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I wish to call attention to the state of things that exists at Hamilton.. We have there a battery of artillery and a regiment of infantry ; and without boasting, I may say we are very proud of that battery and of that regiment. We think they ace not exceeded in soldierly qualities by any other regiment or battery im the Dominion. A medical corps has lately been formed there, and during the short time it has been in existence we have had reason to feel equally proud of the commander and men of that corps. Not long since I was asked by the officer commanding to visit the quarters of the medical corps, and I am glad to be able to say, to the credit of the Militia Department, that the medical and surgical equipment provided there by the government was a credit to this country. I do not profess to be able to judge myself of such matters, but I express the opinion of gentlemen who are competent to judge. Nothing could be better, nothing could be more complete than the equipment provided by the minister. But, Sir, I was surprised, when asked to visit the quarters of that corps, to rind that, instead of going to the drill shed and armoury,
I had to go into the middle of the city, half a mile away from the armoury, and into the second story of a business block. Now I have a reason for bringing this matter before the minister. There arc volunteers drilling night after night at this season, and practicing with heavy guns, and at any moment there may be a serious accident, and if an accident should occur it would be easier to get a dozen ordinary medical practitioners than to reach the medical corps at its quarters. I| do not think that is right.
I may say that I was even more astonished to learn that the quarters in which these valuable stores were kept were not provided by the Dominion of Canada, but by the officer commanding the corps and at his own expense. I think that is not credible to this Dominion. I make these remarks with reference to what the minister has said as to the providing of accommodation not being entirely within his control. The Minister of Public Works, I believe, as things go at present, has to be consulted in all such matters. I do not know wiether >
he Minister of Militia and Defence has any control over the 40,000 rifles that he has spoken of, but if be has not, I think he ought to apply to the Major General for a permit to take one of those rifles with a bayonet, and poke up tbe Minister of Public Works to compel him to provide us with proper accommodation at Hamilton for the medical corps. Accidents might very possibly

happen to the men in gun drill. Some years ago the officer commanding the battery at Hamilton was injured in camp, and that gentleman will go to his grave limning because there were not then at baud the necessary surgical appliances. Such accidents may happen at any time to the men of the corps in the spring of the year, and I think it is not to the credit of the government- I do not like to say it is to the discredit of the Militia Department, because it does not entirely rest with the Minister of Militia ; but it is not to the credit of the government that after forming and equipping a medical corps, that corps should not be, in case of accident, immediately available.

There is a great deal of force and truth in what my hon. friend has said. He must not forget, however, that when the Hamilton drill hall was constructed, in fact all the drill halls, there were no bearer companies then, and there was no army medical corps or staff in existence, you may say, in this country. It was not then contemplated to give accommodation to a corps of any kind to which the hon. gentleman refers, though we can all see now that such a corps is absolutely necessary, and one of the most important parts of the system. Therefore a place had to be found outside. I was not aware that the commanding officer of the bearer company was paying rent for the building, I was under the impression we were paying it. I know we are paying rent in other places, and we should pay rent in Hamilton. My hon. friend, however, will be glad to know that I hope to be able, out of this vote, to make some provision adjacent to that drill hall for the corps of which he speaks. That is one of the things which we contemplate doing with the money now being voted.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I do not assert positively that the commanding officer is paying the rent, but I understand he is. I shall be glad to know that the government is paying the rent
We are paying it everywhere else.	.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: The most serious objection is that the medical corps are quartered nearly half a mile away from the drill shed. I think that state of things should not exist one minute longer than it can be remedied.
I agree in that view.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I notice in the report of the Major General that during the year 1901, he mentions drill halls as having been built at Windsor, Dundas, Kingston and Vancouver, and central armouries at Aurora, Barrie, Charlottetown, Chatham, Fredericton, Galt, &c. I would like to know whether
this means that an armoury has been erected in the town of Galt. It says so on page 41 ?

I am not prepared to give an answer with regard to this particular place. The report means, I think, that armouries have been established within the buildings. The Militia Department does not construct new buildings ; but under the Act we may add to buildings already in existence, or repair or alter them. So I assume that must mean that in Galt some change has been made in the building for providing a central armoury for the battalion of infantry.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
The report here says that it had been completed. Now in the town of Galt the agricultural society of the south riding of Waterloo, erected a new building, and in this building they rented a room, I understand, for an armoury, for which the government pays them $40 per annum. This report is misleading if it means that the government has erected a building there for armoury purposes. I would like to say that in the county of Waterloo, where we have a regiment, there is just one armoury for one of the companies in the town of Hespeler, and that itself is a make shift.
I think it would be proper for the government to enlarge the regiment which we have in Waterloo, and which is composed of six companies. I understand that there should be eight companies in a regiment. We can easily have two companies more. The town of Waterloo is very anxious to organize a company, Berlin would form another company, and Preston could form a company. The county of Waterloo is so situated that one-half of the regiment, located in Hespeler, Preston and Galt, would have the advantage of electric railway communication. They would have four companies at these places, and then four other companies would be located, twq at Berlin, one at Waterloo and one at Hamburg. We could then have a full regiment, and we should have armoury and drill shed accommodation for half of the battalion in Galt, and for the other half in Berlin. Is it the intention of the government to erect these buildings ? I understand, a few years ago-I do not know whether it was just before an election -there was some land purchased in the town of Berlin for the purpose of erecting a drill shed and armoury. Unfortunately in North Waterloo the election went by acclamation and we have heard nothing since in regard to it. I think when we have in that county men who are willing to fight the battles of the country, we should provide them with armouries so as to give them a chance.

I can assure my hon. friend (Mr. Clare), in all sincerity, that the election had nothing to do, nor will it have anything to do' with the policy of the Militia

Department as to where armouries are located. They are located at the headquarters of the battalion, and that will be done regardless of the results of elections. In regard to this particular battalion to which my hon. friend has referred, I have no doubt that what is meant is that the room in Galt has been fitted up at the expense of the Militia Department. Some expenditure has been made, and no doubt the name is included there, because there has been an expenditure. Perhaps the engineer should have been more particular as to the nature of it. That is the reason it is in the list. There has been some expenditure in connection with arm racks, or the means of taking care of the equipment and furniture.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Was there a site purchased for the erection of a drill hall at Berlin a couple of years ago?
I think not.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I understood the statement was made that there had; been.
No.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: In the list of drill halls and central armouries that have been completed during 1901, I notice that the Toronto central armoury is conspicuous by its absence. That hall has not been completed yet, but I am very glad to hear from the hon. Minister of Militia and Defence that it is within the province of the Department of Militia to add to or alter the buildings that have been erected for militia purposes by the Public Works Department.
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: We have brought the question of the completion of the Toronto drill hall before the hon. Minister of Militia and Defence and the hon. Minister of Public Works again and again, but there seemed always to be a divided authority. When we appealed to the hon. Minister of Public Works we were referred to the hon. Minister of Militia and Defence, and when we appealed to that hon. gentleman, we were referred by him to his colleague. Now, however, he has made the statement, and I am very glad to hear it from him, that it is quite within the province of the Militia Department to complete a building, to add to a building, or to alter it.
Not to complete.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: We only want him to add the accommodation that is so urgently required, and we shall certainly after this hold the hon. Minister of Militia and Defence himself, and not the hon. Minister of Public Works, responsible if the work is not done with reasonable expedition.
I think my hon. friend (Mr Clarke) is a little bit astray yet. I understand him to say that the building in Toronto is not completed.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: No.

Therefore, the Public Works Department have not yet got through with their job, and I must refer the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clarke) to the department Which undertook the construction of this building to see that they complete it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I would like to ask the hon. minister if any provision is made in this grant for the better accommodation of arms in the town of Brampton. This is the matter that was up for consideration last year.

I may say to my hon. friend (Mr. Blain) that under the regulations by which the arms are distributed to the headquarters of companies, a good many armouries that were under consideration will be unnecessary, and I cannot say whether this is one of them or not. What is the number of the hon. gentleman's battalion?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: The 36th Peel Battalion.
I have the list here and I will look at it in the meantime and see whether it is included.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
Perhaps it may be well to See what the Major General says on this question of armouries. He says :
I have also observed that where rural regiments have been provided with central armouries, there is a decided leaning on the part of commanding officers to gradually convert their commands into city corps, to the very great detriment of the service, for, however good the city regiments may be, the bulk of our defence force must be the hardy men of our rural units, and anything which has a possibility of weakening that portion of the active militia is, in my opinion, greatly to be deprecated
I, therefore, recommend that 'central armouries ' should cease to be provided for rural regiments, and that, in their stead, plain substantial buildings should be hired, as at present, for company armouries at the company headquarters.
Perhaps that would do away with a lot of the promises that are made by the Public Works Department for political purposes to put up buildings throughout the country. I will be very glad indeed if some of the patronage of that department is wiped out by taking away telegraph lines and armouries from it. If the Public Works Department were shorn of a lot of that patronage, we would have less politics in that department.

I would like to ask the hon. Minister of Militia and Defence what the policy of the department is in connection with this matter that the hon. member

for Bast Elgin (Ml-. Ingram) lias spoken about. Some military people in my constituency belonging to the 30th regiment, feel very strongly about this matter. They think it will be most unwise to establish central armouries at the headquarters of the regiment, and I understand that they have communicated that view to the minister. They think it would be a mistake to build a large armoury in the city of Guelph, and this notwithstanding the fact that some of the people holding that view live in the city of Guelph themselves. They spoke to me about it. They expressed the belief that it would be better to provide accommo-* dation at the company headquarters and not at the headquarters of the regiment. When I was home during the recess I was spoken to about it, and I know there is quite, a strong feeling in the regiment that instead of erecting a large building at the headquarters of the regiment the minister should provide accommodation at the company headquarters. Will the minister tell us what his policy is in regard to that matter-?

I agree with the recommendation of the Major General that we should provide armouries, or suitable rooms, at the company headquarters, and on the strength of that recommendation, rifles will be immediately issued to the rural battalions and disposed of in that way. I do not think it will be necessary to construct a building in all cases, perhaps not in many cases, because suitable rooms can be found. That is the policy which has been adopted.
speakername: The MINISTER OP MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I understand that about a month ago a delegation from Montreal composed of the officers of the Montreal regiments came up to Ottawa and urged the establishement of a military school. Has any progress been made in that connection ?

I will have to refer my hon. friend (Mr. Lemieux), I think, to the hon. Minister of Public Works, as well as my hon. friend from Toronto (Mr. Clarke). As a matter of fact, what my hon. friend says is quite correct, and I may say to him that I consider it a matter of importance that there should be a depot established at the most important centre of trade and population in Canada, Montreal. The matter has not been fully discussed yet, and I think it would be premature to say what would be done this year.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I wish to direct the attention of the Minister of Militia and Defence to the report of the chief engineer of his department respecting military buildings. This report is very pregnant now, and if the recommendation which the chief engineer made were carried out we would know whom to hold responsible for the unreasonable delays which have occurred. The report says : '
The present system by which the Public Works Department construct all military buildings is very unsatisfactory, and considerable trouble and delay is occasioned thereby. I would strongly urge the necessity of having the construction, as well as the maintenance. and repairs of these buildings under the charge of the engineer branch of the Department of Militia and Defence.
Might I ask the minister :	What is the
policy of the department respecting this recommendation ? Has the government decided to carry it out or not ?

I have already stated that I have no hesitation in saying that I believe that it would be in the public interest to have the construction of military buildings under the control of the Militia Department. So far no action has been taken with reference to that.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: This would be a very good time to carry out the recommendation made by the officer of the department.
It would require an Act of parliament.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
We could rush that
through in very short order if absolutely necessary. There is a good opportunity for doing so just now. I find that the chief superintendent of stores also makes a report in reference to the condition of military store buildings which emphasizes the necessity for a change in the present method of constructing and maintaining militia buildings. This officer says on page three of his report:
Store Buildings.
Reference is requested to recommendations on this subject, in previous reports. New store buildings are urgently required in Toronto and Kingston. Those now in use are constructed of wood, very old, and in constant need of repair. No proper care can be taken of the valuable material stored in them.
I would remind the Minister of Militia and Defence that so deficient is the military store accommodation in the city of Toronto, that some of the municipal buildings have been given to the department in which to store valuable military supplies. In view of the reports made by the superintendent of military stores, and by the chief engineer of the department, this matter should be immediately given attention to. We should be able to hold some minister responsible for the unreasonable delay in completing the drill shed in Toronto. Now that the attention of the Minister of Militia and Defence has been called to the matter, and now that he has assumed a reasonable measure of responsibility, I trust that we shall have no more cause for complaint.
Would the Minister of Militia and Defence now answer my question w'ith regard to a drill shed in Brampton.

I do not find any mention of that particular matter but as this is a general vote it is possible to use it for urgent purposes as they arise. I shall be very glad to look into the matter to see if what the hon. gentleman (Mr. Blain) refers to lias been recommended, or whether it will still 'be required under the changed conditions to which I have referred as to the distribution of arms to the country companies.
Militia-Provisions, supplies and remounts, $130,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I want to say a word on a subject somewhat cognate to this vote. The system which has been carried out by Major Dent heretofore in purchasing remounts has not given satisfaction, although I believe that he is now making a change which will be more likely to meet with approval than the original system. At first remounts were purchased generally through one party, and if rumour can be relied upon that party made a great deal of money and did very little work. Those who purchased horses and brought them to Toronto complain that they were obliged to sell them through Grand's old firm, which had a substantial rake off on every animal purchased. The result was that the buyer was obliged to purchase them at a very low figure, and he could not get as good a class of horses on account of the low prices. He was obliged to sell them to this firm and the firm for doing nothing at all, except perhaps supplying a suitable place for the inspection of the horses, made a substantial rake off. While the Militia Department here may have no control over the matter, yet we have always believed that if they made representations to the War Office that it would be more in their interest and in the interest of the people of Canada if a different system were adopted, that representation would be attended to. It would be a much better plan to have the horses sent to the exhibition grounds in Toronto where they could be inspected at certain dates and purchased if found suitable. In this way a better class of animals would be supplied at a lower cost to the War Department, and our farmers would get better prices. I notice of late that there is greater latitude allowed to the buyers of horses, and so far that this is an improvement. I hold that there should be the greatest freedom in this matter, and even the individual farmer should be able to send his animals to Toronto and have them examined and purchased direct from him. That system would be better for the Imperial authorities, and the farmers of Ontario would get a better price for their animals.
All the horses were not bought in Toronto.
No, but a large number were.

As the hon. gentleman (Mr. Sproule) says : This is not our concern nor do I think it would be advisable for us to offer advice unless it were asked. When my hon. friend the Minister of Agriculture was in England last year he had an opportunity of discussing this very question with the War Office, and he and I have been trying to induce the Imperial authorities to establish regular and permanent remount stations in this country for the purchase of horses. Up to this date nothing has been done, but I hope that something may be done, in which case officers of either the Department of Agriculture or of my own de-jjartment would deal directly with the people. It has been suggested that fairs might be- held, not necessarily at Toronto, but at country centres once a month, to which horses might be brought, and that men should be sent out to select the horses on the spot. I hope something of that kind will grow out of the negotiations now going on.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: That would be preferable, for this reason, that a large percentage of the horses sent to Toronto are culled out, and they have either to be put up at auction and sold at whatever they will bring, or else are left on the buyer's hands. If he sells them, he is obliged to take a lower price than the animal is worth if bought at home, besides paying the cost of sending them there.

That is quite true, and I think the amount of money which these dealers have been credited with having made is altogether incorrect. As my hon. friend says, they have had left on their hands a large number of horses which they could not dispose of or had to sell at auction at very low figures, which has eaten up a very large part of -the profit.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: My understanding is that if a buyer consigned a number of horses to Silver and Grand of Toronto, he would only be responsible for the number selected out of that consignment and he would get something like $5 or $10 for each horse taken by the purchaser, but the culls would be left on his hands.

I happen to know of one case in which fully 1-2$ per cent of the horses consigned to the Grand firm were thrown on their hands, and they actually lost that number of horses, or had to dispose of them at very low figures.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I may say that the officer who is here purchasing on behalf of the War Office has considerably modified the original system, and for more than a year back has been purchasing in a large number of centres. When he first began purchasing he only went to two

or tln-ee centres-perhaps Toronto, Ottawa and Montreal ; but lately he has been going to a large number of centres, and has been having the horses brought there. What my hon. friend the Minister of Militia says is quite true in many instances. I do not think the officer himself knows altogether what the arrangements are between the man who brings in the horses and the original owners of them ; but I know of my own personal knowledge that in many cases the contractors found on their hands a large number of rejected horses which they had to dispose of as best they could. In addition to that, they were under considerable expense. They had to keep the horses from one to two weeks before the officers came round, trim them, and in some cases bridle and bit them and manage them. So that the business is not quite as profitable as at first sight it appears. 1 have no doubt these contractors have been making some money ; it is not likely they would engage in the business if they did not ; but I think I may say that the prices of horses in Canada has been materially raised in consequence of the purchases of the War Office within the last two years, and it has helped to relieve our own market of a large number of horses which otherwise would not have been easily sold.
I know that prices have been materially raised, because many of these horses were bought from the farmers at as low as $65 or $70 and sold to the War Office at $140.
No, no.

X know what I am talking about, because I saw some of the animals purchased. I moved for a return on the subject in this House, and I found that these horses had been sold to the War Office at an average price of $140. But that has been changed, and the farmers are at present getting comparatively good prices for their horses. If, as the minister suggests. fairs are held at different localities, where the farmers can bring in their horses or the contractors could have them selected direct by the party sent around to make the selection, that would be in my judgment the very best plan that could be adopted.
Grants to associations, $38,000.

This is the usual vote. Ontario gets $1,800, Quebec $1,700, Nova Scotia $1,500, New Brunswick $1,300, Manitoba $750, British Columbia $620. and Prince Edward Island $630, making $8,300. The grant to battalion rifle associations and to bands range from $25 to $200 each, according to strength and efficiency, about 90 of each. The artillery grant is all paid to the Artillery Association. There is the grant to the dominion Rifle Association and the grant to local rifle associations $6,500. The bands of the 81
active miliiia receive $7,500, and military institutes $300.
Contingencies, $22,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OE MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: This includes printing and stationery, $12,000; military survey, $4,000. This is a topographical survey, done by cadets at the Royal Military College, under the direction of their professors.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: What was done with it afterwards ?

It is in the Intelligence branch of the Quartermaster General's office. It is a most careful survey of the country along the frontier, giving every road, the height of hills and the buildings. It is a magnificent piece of work, well worth examining.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: How much of the country has been done ?

We have been doing the work for the last five years. I could not say the number of miles. Then there is advertising $1,500; injuries at annual drill. $3,000; telegraph and legal expenses, &c., $3,500. When we came to office we had a smaller vote, but two years ago we adopted the plan of making the vote large enough to cover expenses, so that we will not have to ask any supplementary vote.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: What are those injuries ?

Injuries to men, but more particularly to horses. Every year there is a certain number of horses killed or rendered useless, and we pay for them at a rate not exceeding $100 per horse.
Royal Military College, $75,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I would call the attention of the minister to some comments by the commandant on this institution :
It is a matter for great regret that this admirable institution', established for the express purpose of securing for the Canadian militia a supply of well trained and capable officers, entirely fails to attain this object. What brought about this state of things it is impossible to say, but one thing seems clear, that in the period spent at the college, the students do not imbibe any soldierly ambition or acquire a taste for military employment, and it is sad to see, year after year, young gentlemen who have received such an excellent military education at great cost to the state, holding aloof from the service of their country.
Has the minister given any consideration to those comments ?

I have read very carefully the General's report, and while I agree with him to some extent, I do not think that he should have made so strong a case. He



is quite mistaken when lie says that no military spirit is imparted to the cadets. As a matter of fact, tliere are now in the British army nearly a hundred cadets of the Royal Military College Had he said that the young men were not entering our militia or permanent corps, he would have spoken more correctly. But I do not see how we can remedy this. We might require each young man, on entering the school, to undertake to join a corps of Canadian militia after he came out, but I think that would be rather difficult. What I hope is that in the future more graduates of the college will come into our permanent corps. We have scarcely any there now, because they do not consider it good enough for them. They prefer going to the British army, where they have a career, which our permanent force does not offer. Besides we have no pensions, so that there is very little but hard work to offer them, and nothing at the end. But now we have a pension and hope to greatly raise the character of the permanent corps. So far as the active militia is concerned, every cadet who graduates is a member of the Canadian active militia and available for service when required. Many of these young men are now in the active militia throughout the country, and when the South African trouble came, we found dozens of them who were working throughout Canada as engineers, offering their services. There was a large number on the second contingent and in the Strathcona Horse, and a considerable number are now in the squadrons in the last contingent, so that I do not think the condition is as hopeless as the Major General thinks.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
Wliat percentage of the graduates is in the Canadian militia and also in Canada ?
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. I had these figures a year or two ago and gave them to the House. I asked for the statement this morning, but have not yet received it, but will give the information on the supplementaries.

Was it in the ' Hansard ' last year	?
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. Either that or the year before.

This school
seems to be regarded more as a school for educating an engineer than to fit young men for the military career. I do not know exactly how the difficulty is to be got over, but it seems rather discouraging. Are there any graduates of that school in the permanent force ?
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. Yes, two or three.

How many
does the school turn out annually ?	*
, The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE. Now over thirty. For a good many years there were only from seven to ten.
A certain number go into the Imperial service ?
Yes, a very large number went last year.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I suppose that is something that might be placed to our credit-that we do afford a military education to officers which go into the service every year. Is the education provided by this institution regarded as at all equivalent to the training given by similar institutions in England ?
Quite as good.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: It is placed on the same plane ?	.
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Has the hon. gentleman any idea how many men there are in the Imperial service who are graduates of this college ? I suppose the statement he refers to would give that ?
I think it is over a hundred.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I see by the Auditor General's report, page Q-91 that William Allan and Son of Kingston received $2,430.15 for boots. &c., and at page Q-93 C. Livingston and Bros., received $7,649.99 for clothing. Were these goods purchased by tender ?
I think not.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
I should think not by the prices that I see charged here, and by the fact that these gentlemen are very strong partisans of hon. gentlemen opposite. Messrs. Allan supplied 49 pairs of long boots at $10, and 10 pairs of riding boots at $10 a pair, also 194 pairs of short boots at $6 a pair. Then, Messrs. Livingston supplied, for instance blouses at $2.50 each, 4 great coats and 2 capes, $73 ; 30 coats at $10.50 ;
8 pairs of gloves at 25 cents and 170 pairs at $1 a pair. I suppose these are kid gloves for the young gentlemen we have there. It seems to me the furnishing of supplies for that Military College ought to be by tender and not by going to a friend of the party at Kingston and paying these large prices, when the amount is over $7,600.

That has never been done, and it would be very difficult to do. These young gentlemen have to be measured for the boots or clothing they get. It is not like asking for a large quantity of clothing for general use to be distributed among men according

as it happens to fit. In this case they are the prices of the tailor and shoemaker-retail prices.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Retail prices ?

Certainly.
Militia-chargeable to income-Dominion Arsenal, $150,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OE MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: There is an increase here of .$32,000. What is the explanation of that ?

That is for the manufacture of cartridges. This increase of $32,000 is taken from what would have been the vote for annual drill and stores. As I pointed out, we are increasing the output of cartridges enormously, and this is to pay for wages, as we must employ more labour.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Is there anything in this vote for additional machinery, or anything [DOT]of that kind ?

No, all labour.
Militia-chargeable *to income-defences at Esquimalt, $114,703.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: What is being done there ?
There is an increase over last year of $2,433.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: According to the estimates before us there is a decrease of over $10,000.

speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Is it all expended by this government, or is any part expended by the Imperial government ?

It is expended by the Imperial government, except the portion that is for the maintenance for the local militia which is supposed to be maintained at the establishment fixed by the agreement, and cost $10,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
What percentage of the whole cost are we to bear ?
The MINISTER OF MI LUl IA AND DEFENCE. We are to bear one-half the total expenses.
Outsiue of the militia what is the expense ?

speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I understand, but for what purpose, is it labour, is it buildings, or what 1
The maintenance of the Imperial garrison of 320 officers and men including engineers and artillery.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: And besides that, we have our own ?

Yes.
Militia-chargeable to capital-rifle range, $75,-
000.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I would like to change the words there, so as to make them read ' for the purchase of land and the equipment of rifle ranges.' The work we have done for this vote since it was begun two years ago included the construction of the rifle range here, the expenditure on which I gave last session ; the rifle range at Montreal, the expenditure on which I gave a day or two ago in answer to a question by the hon. member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) ; rifle ranges at Hamilton, Halifax-or near Halifax-St. John, Fredericton, London, Victoria, Sherbrooke and other places, besides one undertaken at Winnipeg. These are first-class rifle ranges, 1,000 yard ranges, up tq date in every respect. I am told that the rifle range at Ottawa is one of the best in the world. The one in Montreal, though not quite so large, is equally good.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I think the minister said yesterday that the rifle range in Montreal would cost $35,000.

That was the cost of the buildings and the work alone. I think the land cost $30,000 or $40,000, and the total cost will be about $75,000. The range here cost more than that, because we had heavy expenses in the Exchequer Court by reason of the fact that we could not settle with some of the holders of the land. The rifle range at Winnipeg will be something of the same character, but I hope not as expensive. These rifle ranges cost anywhere from $15,000 to $60,000, or $70,000. That at Sherbrooke is much smaller, and will cost $5,000 or $6,000. I may add that we have another vote of $20,000 for cheap ranges in small districts. It will be divided up in sums of from $200 to $500, to assist rural companies.

Many ranges are being constructed in an inexpensive way where one or two targets are sufficient. In these large ranges we have 40 or 50 targets ; in the Ottawa range I think there are 55 targets.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I noticed a short time ago there was a landslide at Quebec. Can that landslide in any way affect the walls of the fortifications ?

No, it is on the front, next to the river. Those slides occur every year.
Some resolutions reported.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: The POSTMASTER GENERAL (Hon. Wm. Mulock) moved the adjournment of the House.
What business is it intended to take up to morrow ?

If there are any government Bills they will be proceeded with, and after that branch of the business is disposed of, we will proceed with the estimates, taking up Agriculture and that part referring to quarantine, and Professor Robertson's branches.
Motion agreed to, and House adjourned at 11.30 p.m.
Ottawa, Friday, April 11, 1902.
